title: Palpable Thyroid Nodule with Suspicious Ultrasound
setup_script: You are the on-call surgeon in a community hospital. A 45-year-old woman presents to clinic with a 2 cm thyroid nodule found on routine physical. She has no compressive symptoms. Ultrasound shows a hypoechoic nodule with microcalcifications in the right lobe and abnormal cervical lymph nodes. Her thyroid function tests are normal.

dynamic_flow.trigger: Discuss importance of history (radiation exposure, family history) and physical exam for thyroid nodules.
Order complete thyroid function tests and neck ultrasound, confirming features suspicious for malignancy.
Explain role of fine-needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB) and request cytology on nodule and suspicious lymph node.
Cytology returns as Bethesda VI (papillary carcinoma) with metastatic lymph node; counsel patient on diagnosis.
Review ATA guidelines for risk stratification and staging; discuss need for total thyroidectomy vs lobectomy.
Decide on total thyroidectomy with central neck dissection given nodal disease; obtain preoperative vocal cord exam.
Explain surgical risks: recurrent laryngeal nerve injury, hypocalcemia, bleeding; obtain informed consent.
Plan perioperative management including referral to anesthesiology, optimization of comorbidities, and discussing postoperative hormone replacement.
Perform surgery; intraoperative finding of gross nodal disease prompts comprehensive central compartment dissection.
Postoperative management: monitor calcium, voice, wound; prescribe levothyroxine and consider radioactive iodine therapy.
Discuss pathology results with patient, including margins and number of positive nodes; arrange oncology referral.
Plan long-term follow-up with thyroglobulin monitoring and ultrasound; educate on symptoms of hypocalcemia and hypothyroidism.

critical_decision_points: Recognizing ultrasound features of malignancy and ordering FNAB.
Appropriate decision for total thyroidectomy versus lobectomy based on tumor size and nodal disease.
Safe operative technique protecting parathyroid glands and recurrent laryngeal nerves.
Postoperative calcium monitoring and hormone replacement therapy.
Counseling on long-term surveillance and need for oncology referral.

rubric.resident_feedback_template: This case assesses your evaluation of a suspicious thyroid nodule. You should have obtained a focused history and ultrasound features, ordered FNAB, interpreted Bethesda results, and recommended appropriate extent of surgery. We also looked for clear communication of risks, operative steps, and postoperative care. Please reflect on how you counseled the patient about treatment options and long-term surveillance.
